name: learning-on-climate-change-and-forest-policy-making
title: Learning on climate change and forest policy making

groups.title: Climate Change Mitigation
groups.description: If the global food supply is to keep pace with population growth and dietary changes, agricultural productivity must increase. Changes in agricultural practices can help the world not only to meet its targets for reducing greenhouse gas emissions but also to contribute to food security.
groups.name: climate-change-mitigation
climate-change-adaptation
groups.description: Climate change threatens our ability to ensure global food security, eradicate poverty and achieve sustainable development. Greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions from human activity and livestock are a significant driver of climate change, trapping heat in the earth's atmosphere and triggering global warming.
groups.title: Climate change adaptation and resilience

notes: A wide variety of materials helping the user to navigate through forest policy making in the context of climate change.

organization.title: FAO
organization.name: fao
organization.description: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations

resources.description: This document is published as part of the effort by the Forestry Department of FAO and the National Forest Programme Facility to assist countries address emerging policy issues related to forests and climate change through integrating climate change considerations into national forest programmes. The aim is to assist senior officials in government iv administrations and the representatives of other stakeholders, including civil society organizations and the private sector, prepare the forest sector for the challenges and opportunities posed by climate change.
resources.name: Climate Change for forest policy-makers: an approach for integrating climate change into national forest programmes in support of sustainable forest management
Tools- Climate Change for forest policy-makers
resources.description: The major strength of this simplified four-stage model is that it reduces the complexity of policy-making to manageable, analytical units, thus facilitating understanding. It also emphasizes that the integration of climate change into NFPs is an iterative process. New developments, experiences and lessons learned need to be reflected in revisions of policies and implementation arrangements.
